resources.string: "Error: Program files could not be found! Check the dalvik-cache location to solve this problem! Default: /data/dalvik-cache/*"
Thanks for english translation: ChelpuS, Ms_Julia, p0izn@xda and mdnk

Lucky Patcher is a universal patching tool that is designed to modify applications. It has the ability to remove ads, remove Google license verification (automatically and manually), manage app permissions and do much more.
This activity is used for advertising.
Shows all apps with Google Ads.
All changes have been fixed in the .odex file and will persist until the application is reinstalled.
Use the Magisk module to apply the patch
Please use Xposed(lSPosed) to apply current patch
Error: APK file could not be found.
Naming scheme for new APK files.
App could not be found! Please install the application and try again.
This app could not be found in the installed apps list.
App Data is empty. There is nothing to backup.
Error: Something went wrong. The backup appears incomplete or corrupted.
Do you really want to delete the backup?
Do you really want to delete backup app settings
Cannot restore application settings because it is not installed.
Do you really want restore backup app settings
No backup files were found in:
Root not stable. Try again or update your root. Try changing the java-root method in the settings of Lucky Patcher. It can help sometimes.
Do you want to try and get this item for free?
To disable auto-repeat, select the app and go to \"Tools\" -> \"Remove selected saved purchases\" and delete the items.

"- For the best results, you must use a patch to Android \"Signature Verification status always True\"; - To disable the hack, go to \"Switches\" at the bottom of Lucky Patcher and disable \"Google Billing Emulation\"."

Requires \"Support patch for InApp and LVL\" to target Application and applied \"Patch to Android\". Use custom patch \"Support.InApp.LVL...\" for Google Play for correct purchase information and price within the application.
Send a reply to the application unsigned (this may work for non-root users)
If the purchase fails, try changing the type of this purchase in \"%1s\"->\"%2s\".
This service is needed for \"Support patch for InApp and LVL emulation\" and rebuild the application with him.
Proxy server for emulation of inapp purchases
Do you want to remove this directory bind?
Binding failed! Data directory could not be found on device.
Warning: Busybox could not be found. Lucky Patcher cannot continue without Busybox...
The magisk module for android patches will be removed. This will restore the original firmware files. Then the device will reboot. Do you agree?
Move data to a new location
Data transfer was disabled because a folder inside the previous one was selected. Data folder changed to %1$s.
"Here you can change Lucky Patcher's icon"
Here you can change the name of the Lucky Patcher to make it easier to find on your desktop.
Make data and cache backups for installation.
%1$s is having trouble with Google Play services. Please try again.
Backup app settings of selected apps
"Block Internet for selected apps May not work on Android 4+"
APK with changed permissions and activities
Removes integrity check and signature verification
Injects code into the application to bypass the dex checksum and signature verification. This method doubles the size of the application.
"Disable components 'pm disable' method (may be enabled by the application)"
Turn back on Google Ads services
Try to hide Lucky Patcher from other apps. Will increase the load on the system - use only if necessary.
Integrate dalvik code to already installed application
Integrate updates of selected apps to /system
Move selected apps to internal storage
Move selected apps to SD Card
Re-sign with original signature for android patch \"%1s\".
Results of batch backup of applications:
Results of batch backup of applications settings:
"Change permissions and activities Rebuild and install"
"Change permissions and activities Save original signature (Safe method)"

"Injects code into the application that tries to trick the application's signature verification. It must be applied strictly for the original application. If the application has already been rebuilt, this will not only not help, but can also harm if the option has already been implemented successfully."
Support patch for InApp and LVL emulation
"Unblock Internet for selected apps May not work on Android 4+"
Select application file to copy signature
You can select another application file to sign your file with a signature from it.
You can copy the signature from an already installed application with the same package name.
Fake a modified APK archive from the original
Tries to bypass file checking by modifying the zip archive. If the archive is modified after this, the method may not work.
Removes http:// links using templates from files AdsBlockList_user_edit.txt and AdsBlockList.txt.
"Patch on Reboot (Unstable! Only for patching libs)"
Necessary for emulations InApp, LVL and keygens. Needed for right verification of purchases and licenses.

"Allows the modification of an application without creating a signature again, so the developer's signature will stay untouched. Other users can install this .apk only after applying a patch to the Android Core (useful when translating, modifying graphics, etc. in protected applications)"
Disable signature verification in the package manager
Allows Installation of applications with different signatures on top of each other.
"+ Allows the installation of applications with an older version than the one that is already installed."
Support patch for InApp and LVL emulation
Needed for emulation to work without the Support patch to Applications.
Remove all patches from the Android services.jar
Remove all patches from the Android core.jar
Attempts to make the app work offline.
If it exists, allow an internet connection on the first launch. This group of patches makes minor changes.
If it exists, there is probably no need for an internet connection on the first launch.
Unstable, but very effective (there may be errors when the \"auto-orientation\" of the device is enabled). If it exists, allow an internet connection on the first launch.
Templates for final license verification. If this works, the application will work without an internet connection.
If \"Final License Verification\" was not successful, you can try these patches.
"Try to break the Google Ads' obtaining mechanism."
Other patches which can be useful to remove ads.
"Make the ad module think that it's offline."
Remove License Verification for applications from the Amazon Market.
Removing Google Play dependencies and others...
The minimal number of patches. Suitable for most applications with simple protection.
There are a few differences from the \"Auto mode\". It may help you, if \"Auto mode\" was unsuccessful.
Additional patches that may cause instability. Apply only if the other patterns were unsuccessful. Requires internet. Try to use together with \"Auto mode\" or \"Auto mode (Inversed)\".

By default all changes are written to odex-file. But this method will not work properly if application has been moved to the external SD card. In this situation the \"Apply Patch to dalvik-cache\" could help. You can restore the application only by re-installation.
"Will copy the application package file to Lucky Patcher's folder on the SD card. You can restore the application from the copied APK."
Deletes dalvik cache of the application to save space after creating the odex-file. If the application does not work well with odex, you will have to reinstall this application.
The minimum number of patches. Only works with google Play installed. When you first start a hacked program, you need the Internet.
Remove License Verification for Apps from SamsungApps.
If device freezes or all patches do not work, please reboot device manually.
"Android Patch for dalvik-cache finished. Results are: "

Dalvik-cache of core.jar has been patched, but this type of Patch can disappear when updating the dalvik-cache. Not enough space in the System ROM for creating core.odex. Please free about 4MB, clear dalvik-cache and try again. Please reboot device to apply patch to dalvik-cache.
Patch dalvik-cache always on reboot (only if patches to core.jar are removed after reboot).
The downloaded file is corrupted. Please check that there is enough free space on the SD Card then try again later.
It does not work for all applications. If the clone is not installed, you need to remove the original. If this method does not work, try to create a clone in a different way.
It does not work for all applications. This method attempts to change the resources and classes.dex. This method creates a clone that is more isolated from the original.
Error: Name of directory is empty.
"Success! The license has been created successfully. Try to test the application while offline. Maybe you'll get lucky."
APK rebuilt for InApp and LVL emulation

"Note! If the application works fine after the patch, there's no guarantee that it will work fine in the modified-apk form - some applications are protected from modification. You will tend to have greater luck with patching, than with modifying."

"Note! Some apps need to be uninstalled before installation of cloned application. There's no guarantee that it will work fine in the cloned-apk form - some applications are protected from modification."
Use your name for the application
Not enough space to paste the code. Reduce size of replace template.
Custom patch is not valid for this version of the program, or the program has already been patched.
Not all patterns are replaced, but the program can work, test it!

"Custom Patch not Found. It's problem with root. Don't have access to SD card from root. If you use SuperSu, try disable \"mount namespace separation\" in SuperSu. If it not help, please update SuperSu and update binary file su from SuperSu."
No updates for custom patches were found.
Shows all apps with a custom patch applied.
The application file is damaged and can be read.

Set the maximum number of days old that an application can be while still being considered new. Set to 0 days if you want to disable the movement of recently installed applications to the top of the list.
The update for com.google.android.art has been removed to bring back patch functionality.
Do you really want to delete file %s?
Uninstall system app for current user
Do you really want to uninstall system app %s for current user?
(mini version with license and inapp emulation only)
Do you really want to remove the updates for the apex module com.google.android.art?
No updates have been found for the apex module com.google.android.art.
%1$s was signed by a original signature successfully. Re-signed file is located %2$s.
%1$s was signed by a test signature successfully. Re-signed file is located at %2$s.

This application is part of the Android operating system. Be very careful while performing any operations on it, because you can soft-brick your device. Do you have a backup? Are you sure you want to work with this application?
"Change the directory on the SD Card where Lucky Patcher will store its files. The default path is /mnt/sdcard/Android/data/[package_name_of_lucky_patcher]/files/LuckyPatcher"
InApp Services to Google Play Store
Some Apps crash if multiple InApp services are enabled.
License Service to Google Play Store
Some Apps crash if multiple license services are enabled.
Your Lucky Patcher has been modified. You can not send a log.
Please update Lucky Patcher to the latest version to send log.

The version of Google Play installed in the system partition is higher than the version being installed. Now the Google Play version below will be installed in the system partition. After that, repeat the installation of the modded Google Play. Do you agree?
You must create at least one bind to add widget.
You are using the latest version of Lucky Patcher.
Failed to backup APK file. The classes.dex files are missing inside the application.
The mechanism for working with signatures is broken, so it is impossible to check the patch \"%1$s\". If the patch is applied using LSposed, you need to change version of LSposed, riru or zygisk.
"You can't install system applications from this location, please move them to sdcard."
Lucky Patcher must be installed on the internal memory. Otherwise, some features may not work properly.
"Lucky Patcher must be installed on the internal memory. This feature doesn't work when Lucky Patcher is on an external memory."
Failed to backup APK file. No permissions to copy.
"The file \".jar\" doesn't contain classes.dex for patch. Try patching \".odex\" file for this \".jar\" file."
An error in the log collector occurred. Log not created.
"Could not create the file join_patch.txt. May not have permissions to write to the patch folder."

"Error creating .oat file for patched classes.dex. Patch has made some errors in classes.dex or some problems with the firmware. Ways to solve problems: 1.Downgrade or upgrade the Magisk version. 2.Try to disable all Magisk modules for the test. 3.Try changing the java-root method in the settings of Lucky Patcher."
"Could not delete the file join_patch.txt Delete the file or the entire patch folder manually."
It appears that Lucky Patcher has force-closed, do you want to send a bug report?
Application is installed, but it was not possible to copy the cache to /Android/obb folder.
File %1s was not found in the original %2s archive. Due to this, the CRC file was not changed.
Could not get the classes.dex files for the patch.
Error: Did not get pkg info.
Lucky Patcher cannot import the custom patch. The zip archive appears to be damaged.
Unable To Share Application. Unknown error. Try changing the working directory for Lucky Patcher.
It was not possible to fit all additional code into the free space of dex files. Repeat the patch and select the smaller options for the patch. Or use a rebuild with this patch.
Data for making a license could not be found.
License location could not be found.
Error: Creating odex process failed... Probably not enough disk space left.
This app does not contain classes.dex. Dex optimization is not possible.
Not enough memory (RAM) to complete this operation. The VM Heap is too small.
Directory already exists. Please enter a new path.
"Patch completed! Launch and check the application's license status; If this pattern doesn't help, tap \"Restore\" and repeat the procedure with another pattern."
"Tags could not be found for this pattern. Already patched? Tap \"Restore\", select another pattern and patch it again."
"Disables the loading of icons from Lucky Patcher's database. This makes the application list laggy..."
"App could not be copied to the SD card! Please free up some space on the SD card or check your busybox installation."

This is a service for monitoring files like .dex, .so, .zip. When such files appear, it tries to copy from the application to /sdcard/Download/application_package_name. This is necessary to get encrypted files from the application. On startup, it will start the service and the application itself. After waiting the required amount of time, you can interrupt the progress dialog, then information about the copied files will be displayed.
Apps with SEND_SMS and CALL_PHONE permissions
Google Play has been installed. Now core.jar will be patched and your device will be rebooted. Continue?
Shows all apps with fixed changes (Yellow star mark).
New folder must be empty. Please select a different folder.
Lucky Patcher did not find any bytes to patch.
Log was not created. An error occurred while creating the log.

"Create log for core-libart.jar (for fix \"Patch to Android\")"
"Create log for core-oj.jar (for fix \"Patch to Android\")"
"Create log for framework.jar (for fix \"Patch to Android\")"
"Create log for services.jar (for fix \"Patch to Android\")"

"Log created and stored in /sdcard/boot.oat.txt.zip. Send it to me in the mail lp.chelpus@gmail.com. File size:"

"% Luck! Please run the application to test the patch!
If the application works incorrectly, please reinstall it and do not try to patch this version of it."
Clear data of google services for fix the problem of logging into google account inside Google Play
This is an application with separated apk files. When creating a backup copy of such an application, a file with the extension \"apks\" will be created (Lucky Patcher can install those files)

P.S.: Lucky Patcher closes an application when it applies a patch to it. This is necessary so that the new changes will persist. However, sometimes you may also need to restart the device itself, use a third-party tool to kill the process or processes of the affected application, or clear application data to see the changes.

*%1$s - A list of applications that will be patched on boot. At the moment, the function is outdated, because all the changes that you make with applications are saved in ODEX and cannot go anywhere, therefore, you do not need to insure yourself by adding applications to the Bootlist. This may only be needed in case, if a custom patch changes the \".so\" libraries of the application. It will be indicated in the description of those custom patches to add them to the Bootlist.
automatically adds this custom patch to \"%1$s\". Should be used in the patch of libraries (or in the patch of [CLASSES] without [ODEX] or without [PACKAGE])
"Add a file from Lucky Patcher directory to the apk archive. Example:"

"Patches all files in the specified directory. \"dir\" - directory for patch files. \"template\" - a template for selecting files for a patch (you can only use \"*\", which means any number of any characters.). Example:"
pattern search/replace for all native libraries

Applies this pattern only for apk with build=apk_build. You can apply pattern for build>=apk_build (Example: {\"apk_build\":\"206+\"}) or can apply for build<=apk_build (Example: {\"apk_build\":\"206-\"}).
You can apply a patch pattern for the apk version interval, for this you need to specify two apk_builds with an upper and lower version boundary:
patch comments that are visible to the user pre-patch
The start mark, all the text after it and up to the first field [CLASSES], [LIB], [END], etc. will be displayed at the beginning of the patch log for the user.
"Blocks listed internet hosts. \"host\" is the host you want to block. Example:"

"Patches dalvik-cache applications. Keep in mind that the system periodically updates dalvik-cache applications and all the changes will disappear. Therefore, we must use [ADD-BOOT]. The patch for dalvik-cache is outdated, as it is unreliable and was only used on older firmware. But it is needed for the ROM Toolbox, because it does not work well with odex-files. Example:"

Applies a patch to one specific classes file, without this option the patch will be applied to all classes*.dex files (for example: {\"classes_name\":\"classes2.dex\"}, {\"classes_name\":\"classes3.dex\"}, {\"classes_name\":\"classes.dex\"} ...).
Here are the lines for the classes.dex patch. These can be search, original-replaced and other options described below.

"Enable or disable components of Applications. Sometimes an application disables its activity and other components in order to limit its functionality, then this ability to enable it back can be useful. So you can include activities, services, providers and other components. The most important thing is to indicate their names in strict accordance with uppercase and lowercase letters. Example:"
"Copies a file from Lucky Patcher's folder to the specified folder with a new file name. Example:"
"This is the path to the database on your device and presumably on other users' devices. You can also specify only the name of its file, then Lucky Patcher will try to find it on it's own."

Everything has been edited, save and drop the file into the \"CustomPatches\" directory located in the Lucky Patcher folder. This folder can be viewed in the \"About\" section at the very top. Then the program is highlighted in yellow, and you can apply this patch to it.
patch comments that are visible to the user post-patch
This is a SQLite query, compiled according to the usual rules (you can read it on the Internet).
pattern search/replace for file inside the apk file (this function only works when rebuilding the application with this custom patch)
- The patch file must have the same name as the target APK (this is case sensitive).

- If a custom patch file for the application already exists, you can simply add any text at the beginning of the file name and save it next to the existing one. In this case, when you select Custom patch in the application, Lucky Patcher will offer you a list of custom patches for the application to choose from.

"- If you want to write a patch for a whole series of programs from one company at once, then at the end of the custom patch file name, you can use the identifier _%ALL%. For example, the patch name for all SVOX voices will look like this: com.svox.classic.langpack_%ALL%.txt. The _%ALL% replaces the part in the package name, which varies depending on the application of the given company. Do not use special characters/formatting in the patch file (single spaces only). If you still need to add your own prefix at the beginning, you can use %ALL%_ and _%ALL% (Example: chelpus.%ALL%_com.android._%ALL%.txt). When displaying custom patch names in the program itself, %ALL%_ is hidden for readability."

- In the text of a custom patch, you can use %PACKAGE_NAME%, which will be substituted with the package name of the target application during the patch. This is useful in application group patches where the file path will change depending on the package name (Example: /data/data/%PACKAGE_NAME%/files/trial.txt).
- To search for patterns of bytes use IDA Pro 6.1+. It can open dalvik-cache, odex, libraries and classes.dex.

- If you want to patch dalvik-cache or odex, do not forget that the bytes of data in different firmware versions may vary. In early versions of android before the introduction of ART, you could patch dalvik cache or odex files, but there you need to take into account that the bytes of the opcodes do not always match the bytes in classes.dex, so when writing such a patch, you need to look at this place by opening the file in IDA Pro.

- Starting with version 6.5.4+, Lucky Patcher has the ability to create files with the lpzip extension. These are zip archives that can contain custom patches and apk files. When opening those zip files in Lucky Patcher, custom patches will be imported, and apk files will be prompted to be installed on the system. (Example: installSomeAppsWithPatch.lpzip)

Marks patterns of the group (group number could be 1 or higher). You may be asking \"What does this mean?\". Well, what it means is that If at least one pattern from the group has succeeded, the user will be shown a dialog that the patch has completed successfully. This is useful when you try to make a universal patch for multiple versions of a particular application (for example, a patch for all versions of Google Play to disable automatic updates).
"Adding and subtracting decimal numbers from the original byte... For example:"

"Is used in cases where it is necessary to replace the found original with a number of bytes different from the number of bytes of the original pattern. Most often this is needed in various text files. For example, when the xml file contains: \"lives=9\", but you need to replace it with \"lives=999\", in this case, insert will help, without changing the data after \"lives=9\". (Example: before the patch, the file contains: \"chelpa end\")"
after the patch the file already contains: \"chelpaa end\"

automatically builds in emulation of purchases and license verification when patching. Useful if the patch bypasses enhanced purchase or license verification. For example, sometimes it helps to fix the GooglePlayValidator method in IL2Ð¡PP and purchases begin to work with the Lucky Patcher.
pattern search/replace for named native libraries (see below)

This means that the lines for the patch of the library of this program will follow, \"name\" is the name of the library (if you put * instead of the name, then all application libraries will be patched).

Sometimes an application has several libraries for different processor architectures, then it is better to use [LIB-ARMEABI], [LIB-ARMEABI-V7A], [LIB-ARM64-V8A], [LIB-MIPS], [LIB-X86] or [LIB-X86_64] for the desired library so that patterns from another library are not applied to the current one.
replaces the code with \"replaced\" for all methods with the same name and returning void
replaces the code with \"replaced\" for a method that returns a boolean and is in a concrete class
Searches and replaces bytes in the code of a method with any differences from other methods

It patches only the code of the selected method itself, excluding the rest of the application code. The \"method name\" field must be specified - this is the name of the method that will be patched. To cut off unnecessary methods, the class of its location \"class name\" is indicated, and if necessary, also \"parameter types\" and \"return type\", so as not to patch anything extra. Names and parameters are written in smali syntax. If you use the \"original\" and \"replaced\" templates after these parameters, then the search will take place inside the method. If only the \"replaced\" template is used, then the entire method code will be replaced with this template and zeros without searching, but in this case the size of the template must be less than or equal to the size of the method code.

"Usually indicates the object to which the patch will be applied. It can be just a file name, a file name with a path, and the like. In some cases, you can use '*' to patch all libraries, for example if the name of the library is unknown."

"There are situations when you need to change an already patched application, for example, for which the license check has already been removed by an automatic patch, then this tag comes to the rescue. All \"original\"-\"replaced\" patterns after it will be applied to the odex file that other patches have already created. For example, this was required for the first time in Final Fantasy III, when people treated the game with Extreme License Check Removal Mode, but in order for the translation to be displayed in the correct encoding, additional patches in the odex file were required, which became possible to apply using this tag. If we use a simple [PACKAGE]-[CLASSES], [ODEX] or [CLASSES]-[ODEX], odex-file will be created with no change and only then patched. In this version of Lucky Patcher, this is no longer required, since there is an option \"%1$s\". Example:"

On older Androids, this tag could be used. Instead of the tag [CLASSES], you can use this one. Then the changes in classes.dex will be saved not in dalvik-cache, where they periodically disappear when the system updates the cache, but in a separate file with the odex extension next to the apk of the application, which will fix all the changes and leave the original dalvik-cache intact - this is just in case, if the application checks it. You can use [ODEX] after [CLASSES], then the changes will be made to the dalvik cache and automatically committed to odex. This is not necessary on modern firmware.
In offset, we specify the offset from the beginning of the file in hexadecimal format, where the byte sequence specified in \"replaced\" or \"insert\" will be inserted.
This is a pattern mask used to find the offset where the patch will be applied.
In this example, the bytes make up the pattern mask, and (??, **) means any byte.
pattern search/replace for any files in /data/data/Package_Target_APK/ or in /sdcard (see below)
unpacks classes.dex and applies all the patches from the [CLASSES] to it. And generates, based on the modified classes.dex, odex-file.

This tag means that we will not patch dalvik-cache directly, but we will pull out classes.dex from target application, patch it (with patches that follow the identifiers [CLASSES] or [ODEX]), create an odex image with changes and put into application. This is the image that TitaniumBuckup needs, for example. It checks it and all check-sums inside it must be correct. It is advisable to always use this tag, because such a patch is the most correct, but if it causes any problems, you can do without it.
"Analog linux command \"chmod permissions file_name\" for files from the application data directory (e.g. give read-only rights after editing) Example:"
This will follow an \"original\" statement, this is what the offset will replace with bytes from the file with the specified name (file must be saved near custom patch).
This is done in order to avoid writing very long replacement patterns that are a chore to type into a text file.

This must follow \"original\" or \"offset\" parameter, which is what these bytes will be overwritten with, or written at the specified offset. Bytes in places marked with (?? or **) will remain untouched:
In this example, the bytes W0, W1, W2 were stored as R0, R1, R2 in the previously executed \"search\".

"Sets smali variable to 0 (e.g. converts hex number to: 43->03,54->04...) or 1 (e.g. converts hex number to: 43->13,04->14...) respectively, SQ aligns hexadecimal digits (e.g. converts hex number to: 34->44, 51->11...). For example, there is a variable: const/4 v?,0x00. The question mark shows, that var's number is unknown (for example, after it has been changed in the newer version), but you are sure, that this var equals 0, and you want to set it to 1. In this case pattern will look like this:"
And vice versa, to set variable to 0:

Looks for bytes in positions marked R[0, 1, 2, 3, ...], where number is the number of the cell where the byte is stored (cell numbers must go in order from 0 onwards and must not be repeated). For example:
means that the bytes at those positions will be stored in R0, R1, R2. Now that they are found and saved, you can use them in replacement patterns only by replacing R with W.
"Edits the xml file that stores application settings (you can delete, add and change values). Example:"
"Sometimes in the target application it is necessary to change something in the database to which it writes any events or data, then this identifier comes to help. Example:"

"So here's an example. I compiled it from a number of tags for clarity. In practice, you will need far fewer functions. In the body of the file, we write something like this (the separator is only a single space, otherwise it will give an error):"
Detailed description of tags and their parameters:
turn on the \"%1$s\" option if the application is rebuilt with this patch.

Do not remove jumps or make them unconditional! The Optimizer will crash and your patch will not work on ART! To avoid this, use conditional jumps. For example, if there is a need to jump, replace the jump with the if-eq v0,v0 (bytes: 32 00 ?? ??). If there is no need to jump in a particular place, you can insert a jump such as if-ne v0,v0 (bytes: 33 00 ?? ??); also feel free to use your own equivalent.
Advertisements were found within this application

In the default mode, all changes remain in the ODEX file. Copying to the dalvik-cache can help when ODEX files do not work for the application (for example, when an application is moved to an SD card). However, you will need to reinstall the application to restore it.
Backup APK file to restore later. APK file is saved to backups folder.
Backs up application data from internal memory to the Lucky Patcher folder.
Copy APK file to SD card in the Data Folder of Lucky Patcher. You can reinstall (to restore) the application from this APK.

Creates an installation package APK with the preapplied patches. You should keep in mind, that rebuilt application may not work the same way as an application that has been patched through the patcher. This may be an issue because an application can check itself to find any changes in the code and signature.
Create an unchanged ODEX file of the application.

Sometimes the application does not start after rebuilding, or it complains about an incorrect signature or dex files checksum, or does not make purchases, etc. In this case, this function can help. It injects code that tries to trick the signature verification or dex files checksum verification inside the application. This option should only be applied to the original application. If applied to an already patched one, then this option will break even if it has already been successfully implemented. As a result of this method, the size of the application will double.

Removes chosen permissions, services, activities, etc. This ability is built into Android, and therefore is not harmful. The only thing that can stop working is the modified application, which can easily be fixed by reenabling permissions. Note that after using this method, the application still has the ability to turn everything back on during startup.

Removes permissions of the application (edits system file packages.xml). Be very careful while doing this. On some devices, this method can lead to a Bootloop or other undesirable consequences. Make a backup of the system before you try to disable permissions.

"Attempts to remove license check. Uses only core templates for more app stability after patching. Suitable for most applications with unpretentious protection. (If the percentage gotten using this method is low, make sure that the internet connection is on while using the patched app)"
Attempts to remove license check. The most stable method. After applying the patch to the application, for its first start, you need Google Play installed and a working Internet.
"Same as \"%1$s\" but with some changes that might help in cases where \"%1$s\" didn't."

Attempts to completely remove license check. Uses all Templates. The patched application may become unstable, usually instability occurs when the application is offline. Restarting the application over and over, changing or disabling screen orientation may help. (if the percentage gotten is too low, when you start the application, the Internet must be turned on for a positive result).

The target application must be signed with the developer signature, and not changed by someone else. For a positive effect of patches, you need an installed GooglePlay (Google market) with a valid account entered into it and the Internet turned on when you first start the target application. Try to always remove the license check first using \"%1$s\", if it does not work, try \"%2$s\". If it causes critical errors, you can try to select only some patterns in \"%3$s\"
Tries to remove license verification by using the selected patch groups.
Converts the user application to system application.

This setting is outdated, because on new versions of Lucky Patcher, all of the changes are saved to an ODEX file of the application, which does not change on reboot. This setting can only be useful if a custom patch changes \".so\" libraries of the application, which will be indicated in the description of the patch.
Disable different application activities manually. Some activities have a description of what they do. Activities can be enabled back if the application stops working.
Attempts to remove advertisements. Try using this patch even if Lucky Patcher has not found ads in an application that contains ads. It may remove those ads.
After creating the ODEX file, dalvik-cache of the application is deleted to save space. If the application does not work with ODEX, you will have to reinstall the application.
Removes ODEX file containing the changes. Thus, restoring the application to its original state.
Remove purchases saved through Google Billing Emulation.
Restore application from an APK file in backups folder.
Restore application data stored in internal memory in the /data/data/application_package_name/ folder.

Removes chosen permissions by rebuilding the APK with changes. This method does not change the application signature. This only works on system applications, or on all apps if \"%1$s\" patch is applied to Android.
Similar to safe method, except this method uses new signature and does not keep the original signature. The application may not work correctly using this method if it checks the signature.
Creates a backup APK file of the selected application and shares it through any app.

Sometimes the application does not start after rebuilding, or it complains about an incorrect signature, or does not make purchases, etc. In this case, this function can help. It injects code that tries to trick the signature verification inside the application. This option should only be applied to the original application. If applied to an already patched one, then this option will break even if it has already been successfully implemented.
Adds support for InApp emulation to the application. InApp emulation can be switched on in Toggles menu.

"- Rebuild the target application with a \"%1$s\" - Delete the original application (rename the cache folder so that it is not deleted). - Install the rebuilt version of the application (rename the cache folder back, if there was one). - Enable \"%2$s\" in the Lucky Patcher switches. Everything, you can try to, buy. It rarely works, but miracles happen :)"
"Sometimes, purchase protection uses application signature verification. In this case, using the \"%1$s\" option can help. "

"Apply the first Android patch (%1$s) and install a modified market version 3+. After that, all your purchases will be redirected to the Lucky Patcher, if the option \"%2$s\" is enabled. To return to normal \"legal\" shopping mode, just disable the option \"%2$s\". This method is identical to the work of Freedom and is not inferior to it in efficiency, but is implemented by modifying Google Play itself, which allows you to make purchases without disrupting the operation of Google Play itself.
How to do it? - Install Lucky Patcher :) - Select the lower panel of the Lucky Patcher \"%3$s->%4$s\", select the top item (%1$s) and tap to apply. After a reboot, the first patch in this dialogue should be marked as 2/2 is applied. - (You can skip this step, but it's better to do it this way, because if this doesn't work, then there's no point in doing anything further) If the patch could not be applied, then you can try using the first option of the Xposed Lucky Patcher module; - Launch Lucky Patcher, turn on the internet connection and choose the lower panel \"%3$s->%5$s\", choose the correct version and press install; - Make Google Play test in \"%3$s->%6$s\". "
Apply the first Android patch (Signature verification is always true) and turn on \"%1$s\" switch. After that, all your purchases will be redirected to the Lucky Patcher.

"If you have Xposed on your device, you can to turn on the Xposed module of Lucky Patcher. Attention: you need to enable the fourth option in the Xposed \"%1$s\" module only if you do not have a modified Google Play installed. If the modified Google Play is not installed, then by enabling the first and fourth options, you can make in-app purchases. The fifth option is to try to hide the lucky patcher from the application if it grumbles."

"Apply \"%1$s\" to the target application. After that, all purchases should be redirected to the Lucky Patcher. For this method to work, you must enable \"%2$s\" in the Lucky Patcher switches. This method is useful if you want to buy through emulation only in applications that you patch yourself. Or apply the \"%3$s\" patch (very long) and all purchases will be redirected to Lucky Patcher directly without a proxy."

"- Does not work on all applications, since the InApp purchase code can be hidden in a place inaccessible to the patch. - Is not effective in applications with protection for checking the original information about purchases. "
These are applications in which license verification permissions are found

"Lucky Patcher has made changes to this application. For example, if the clover is lit, but the star is not, then the odex file with changes was not created, but the application's dalvik cache, its libraries, were patched, or the activation and permissions were changed"
These applications are in the Bootlist*

These are system applications. Be very careful when performing any operations with them, as editing these could do irreversible damage to the application or operating system (always make backup copies with appropriate programs).
Application that contains Google InApp purchases

No direct indication of anything was found in this application, but there may be a license check or advertising in it. (most often, a license check in such applications happens if it is in two parts: program + application key)
Lucky Patcher needs root access for all features to work. Without root rights, the program works in a limited mode.
This means that the application has an \"odex\" file found. For modern Androids, the odex file is shown only for system applications.

"If this option is enabled, the next time you buy the same item, the purchase will be made without the purchase dialog of Lucky Patcher (the purchase will immediately come to the application without any questions). It`s necessary, when you collect gold in the application etc., so as not to press every time that you agree to buy :) You can delete auto-purchase by long pressing on the application in the lucky patcher list and selecting \"%1$s\" then removing unnecessary auto-purchases in the list."

"Useful for users without root privileges, for older games and applications, where the authors do not inadvertently check the signature data. This option saves the purchase in the Lucky Patcher's database so that the next time the hacked application starts, the Lucky Patcher informs it that this purchase should be considered purchased. This is necessary for various kinds of subscriptions and other things. How do you know what to enable? You buy, for example, the full version of the application, and the purchase is successful, but after restarting the application, it again considers itself an incomplete version until you buy again. When this option is on, false data about purchase will be sent to the application with a blank signature and there's a chance, that this purchase will be correct and the application will consider itself purchased after restarting.
Users with root privileges better do not use this option, as it can do more harm than good."
A custom patch was found for this application in the directory of Lucky Patcher
"Hides Lucky Patcher's title in the list of applications. Works only on devices with a hardware menu button."

"Press the \"Install\" button to replace the official Google Play Store with a cracked LVL (License Verification Library) version. If the Google Play Store does not work after reboot, install it again. How the modded Google Play Store works: Attention! You *CANNOT* download paid applications for free! 1. You can use GoogleLVL-protected applications without having to crack them. 2. License verification will succeed even while being offline. 3. There is no need to apply license patches any more. 4. It will not work with Billing and License Verification via Proxy. 5. Now when you press the 'Refund' button, it will refund your purchase, but the application will not be uninstalled, therefore you won't need to backup the application prior to requesting a refund. 6. Now Google Play will redirect all purchases to Lucky Patcher for emulating InApp."
